User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux x86_64; en-US; rv:1.9.2.23) Gecko/20110921 Ubuntu/10.04 (lucid) Firefox/3.6.15pre
Build ID: 20110921065755

Steps to reproduce:

hdon@codebad:~/public_html$ cat > test-bug.php
<?php
header('Cache-Control: max-age=31556926'); # cache forever
header('Content-Disposition: attachment'); # suppress firefox handling response
header('Content-Type: text/plain'); # whatever
?>
blah blah
hdon@codebad:~/public_html$ # Now enter URL in firefox, hit enter, save, open, w/e
hdon@codebad:~/public_html$ # hit control+r ... nothing happens
hdon@codebad:~/public_html$ # Now make Firefox cache totally invalid
hdon@codebad:~/public_html$ cat > test-bug.php
NEW VERSION
hdon@codebad:~/public_html$ # in firefox visit URL, always get old version
hdon@codebad:~/public_html$ # cannot invalidate cache of single file in firefox

NOTES:

The "Content-Disposition: attachment" header suppresses Firefox from attempting to handle the server response by simply rendering the plain text body of the response for the user to see. However another route to achieve this outcome is to provide a Content-Type which Firefox cannot handle, thus once again forcing the save/open prompt. You never get a "loaded page" as so to speak, so Reload is never an option for the URL, and opening a new window with the same URL just returns the cached response again.

comments.raw_text: One solution could be allowing someone to hold shift when they press Enter or the "Go to address in location bar" button. The behavior would invalidate the cache at that location in a way similar to holding shift when one reloads with Control+R or pressing the reload button.
